revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name=193rd Glider Infantry Regiment |image=File:USA - 17 ABN DIV.svg |caption=Shoulder Sleeve Insingia |nickname= |motto= |colors= |march= |ceremonial_chief= |type=[[Airborne forces|Airborne]] |role=[[Glider infantry]] |branch={{army|United States}} |dates=1942–1945 |country={{flag|United States}} |allegiance= |command_structure= |size=[[Regiment]] |specialization= |current_commander= |garrison= |battles=[[World War II]] |notable_commanders= Maurice G. Stubbs |anniversaries= |identification_symbol_2=[[File:GliderInfantryBadge.gif|100px]] |identification_symbol_2_label=The [[Glider Badge]]: Worn by U.S. Army airborne soldiers who rode gliders into combat }}
The '''193rd Glider Infantry Regiment''' was an [[airborne forces|airborne]] [[infantry]] [[regiment]] of the [[United States Army]] during [[World War II]]. It was part of the [[17th Airborne Division (United States)|17th Airborne Division]] and fought during the [[Battle of the Bulge]].
==Formation== The 193rd Glider Infantry Regiment was created during [[World War II]] on 16 December 1942. It was officially formed at [[Camp Mackall]], [[North Carolina]] on 15 April 1943 under the command of [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] Maurice G. Stubbs. The regiment was assigned to the [[17th Airborne Division (United States)|17th Airborne Division]] and sailed to [[England]] in 1944 in preparation for fighting on the [[Western Front (World War II)|Western Front]].
==World War II== During [[Operation Market Garden]] in September 1944, the 17th Airborne Division was held in reserve, and continued to train at Camp Chisleden in [[England]]. Almost three months later, on 16 December, the [[German Army (Wehrmacht)|German Army]] launched a surprise attack, known as the [[Battle of the Bulge]] and the 17th Airborne Division, including the 193rd Glider Infantry Regiment, were finally sent to combat. The 17th Airborne Division was attached to [[General (United States)|General]] [[George S. Patton|George Patton's]] [[United States Army Central|U.S. Third Army]] and ordered to immediately close in at [[Mourmelon-le-Grand|Mourmelon-le-Grand Airfield]]. After taking over the defense of the [[Meuse (river)|Meuse River]] sector from [[Givet]] to [[Verdun]] on 25 December, the 17th Airborne Division moved to [[Neufchâteau, Luxembourg Province|Neufchateau, Belgium]], then marched through the snow to Morhet, relieving the [[28th Infantry Division (United States)|U.S. 28th Infantry Division]] on 3 January 1945 and establishing a Division Command Post.
A howling blizzard with below freezing temperatures greeted the 193rd on the morning of 4 January 1945. Patton had ordered the 17th Airborne Division to seize the town of Flamierge where the [[11th Armored Division (United States)|11th Armored]] and the [[87th Infantry Division (United States)|87th Infantry Divisions]] had encountered brutal resistance from the Germans. Two regiments, the [[513th Parachute Infantry Regiment (United States)|513th Parachute Infantry]] on the right and the [[194th Glider Infantry Regiment (United_States)|194th Glider Infantry]] on the left attacked the town of Flamierge while the 193rd GIR and the [[507th Parachute Infantry Regiment (United States)|507th Parachute Infantry Regiment]] were held in reserve to counter an anticipated German [[panzer]] [[counterattack]]. In the ensuing days, the 193rd GIR, as well as the rest of the 17th Airborne Division, would gain their baptism of fire that would have tested the mettle of the most experienced airborne units. The fighting was so intense that the area would forever be called "Dead Man's Ridge" because of the high casualty count sustained in order to take the strongly defended German emplacements.
By 11 January the German lines were crumbling and all of the 17th Airborne units regrouped except for the 193rd which drove on with American armored units to seize the town of [[Houffalize]]. On 16 January the 193rd rejoined the rest of the 17th Airborne and relieved the 11th Armored Division in pursuit of the [[9th Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)|9th Panzer Division]], the [[Panzer Lehr Division]], and the [[26th Infantry Division (Wehrmacht)|26th Infantry Division]]. This took the 17th Airborne through Flamizoulle, Gives and on to [[Bertogne]] as the Germans continued retreating toward the [[Siegfried Line]].
Beyond Bertogne, 193rd GIR split into "Task Force Stubbs" and "Task Force Bell" with the combined objective of seizing the town of Compogne and the high ground in its immediate vicinity. Turning east from that area the 193rd along with the 507th PIR led the continuing attack across [[Luxembourg]] to the [[Our (river)|Our River]] on the border of [[Germany]]. The [[5th Parachute Division (Germany)|German 5th Parachute Division]] made a vain attempt to maintain a bridgehead at the Our but the 507th managed to cross into Germany and probe the Siegfried Line.
The 17th Airborne Division was finally relieved by the [[6th Armored Division (United States)|6th Armored Division]] and returned to camp at [[Châlons-en-Champagne|Chalons-sur-Marne]] in [[France]] on 11 February 1945. The 193rd Glider Infantry Regiment was disbanded on 1 March 1945 in [[Belgium]] in a reorganization of the [[XVIII Airborne Corps]], of which the 17th Airborne Division formed a part. The [[550th Airborne Infantry Battalion (United States)|550th Airborne Infantry Battalion]] was also disbanded. Both units had suffered heavy casualties during the Ardennes Campaign and the remaining troopers were consolidated into the 3rd Battalion of the 194th Glider Infantry Regiment.
==References== 1. http://www.ww2-airborne.us/units/193/193.html
[[Category:World War II]] [[Category:Airborne divisions]] [[Category:Airborne warfare]] [[Category:Airborne operations of World War II]] [[Category:Airborne operations]] [[Category:Infantry regiments of the United States Army|193]] [[Category:Airborne units and formations of the United States Army]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|2010 GA|6}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | name = {{mp|2010 GA|6}} | background = #FFC2E0 | image = 2010GA6 in April 8 2010.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = {{mp|2010 GA|6}}, captured by [[Purple Mountain Observatory]] in 8 April 2010 | discovery_ref =   | discoverer = [[Catalina Sky Survey|CSS]] | discovery_site = [[Mount Lemmon Observatory|Mount Lemmon Obs.]] | discovered = 5 April 2010 | mpc_name = {{mp|2010 GA|6}} | alt_names = | pronounced = | named_after = | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[List of Apollo asteroids|Apollo]] 
[[Mars-crosser]] | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 23 March 2018 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458200.5) | uncertainty = 6 | observation_arc = 4 days | aphelion = 3.6863 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 0.9292 AU | semimajor = 2.3078 AU | eccentricity = 0.5973 | period = 3.51 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (1,281 days) | mean_anomaly = 87.507[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.2811|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 9.7541° | asc_node = 197.67° | arg_peri = 34.334° | moid = 0.0040 AU (1.6 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|LD]]) | mean_diameter = {{convert|22|m|ft|abbr=on|sp=us}}
{{val|19|u=m}} {{small|(est. at [[Geometric albedo|0.20]])}}
{{val|36|u=m}} {{small|(est. at [[Geometric albedo|0.057]])}} | rotation = | albedo = | spectral_type = | abs_magnitude = 25.9{{·}}26.0 }} '''{{mp|2010 GA|6}}''' is a micro-[[asteroid]] on an eccentric orbit, classified as a [[near-Earth object]] of the [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo group]]. It was first observed on 5 April 2010, by astronomers of the [[Catalina Sky Survey]] at [[Mount Lemmon Observatory]], Arizona, United States, four days before a close approach to Earth at 1.1 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distances]] on 9 April 2010. It has not been observed since. == Orbit and classification == {{mp|2010 GA|6}} is an [[Apollo asteroid]]. Apollo's [[List of Earth-crossing minor planets|cross the orbit of Earth]] and are the largest group of [[near-Earth objects]] with nearly 10 thousand known members. It orbits the Sun in the [[Kirkwood gap|inner]] main-belt at a distance of 0.93–3.69 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 3 years and 6 months (1,281 days; [[semi-major axis]] of 2.31 AU). Its orbit has a high [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.60 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 10[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]]. With an [[aphelion]] of 3.69 AU, it is also a [[Mars-crossing asteroid]], as it crosses the orbit of the Red Planet at 1.666 AU. === Close approach === With a 1-day [[observation arc]], {{mp|2010 GA|6}} had a 1 in 6 million chance of [[impact event|impacting Earth]] in 2074. It was removed from the [[Sentry (monitoring system)|Sentry Risk Table]] on 8 April 2010. The asteroid has now a [[minimum orbital intersection distance]] with Earth of {{convert |0.004005 |AU |km mi|abbr=on |lk=off |sigfig=3 |order=flip}}, which corresponds to 1.6 lunar distances, and is notably larger than the nominal distance of its 2010-flyby. ==== 2010 flyby ==== On 9 April 2010, 02:07 UT, the asteroid passed Earth at a nominal distance of {{convert |0.0029 |AU |km mi|abbr=on |lk=off |sigfig=3 |order=flip}} or 1.1 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distances]]. A stony asteroid 22 meters in diameter can be expected to create an [[air burst]] with the equivalent of 300 [[kilotons]] of TNT at an altitude of {{convert|21|km|ft|sp=us}}. Generally only asteroids larger than 35 meters across pose a threat to a town or city. There are no projection of future close approaches to Earth available. == Physical characteristics == According to NASA astronomers, {{mp|2010 GA|6}} measures approximately {{convert|22|m|ft|sp=us}} in diameter. Based on a generic magnitude-to-diameter conversion, the asteroid measures between 19 and 36 meters in diameter, for an [[absolute magnitude]] of 22.6, and an assumed [[Astronomical albedo|albedo]] between 0.057 and 0.20, which represent typical values for [[C-type asteroid|carbonaceous]] and [[S-type asteroid|stony]] asteroids, respectively. == Numbering and naming == This [[minor planet]] has neither been numbered nor [[List of named minor planets (alphabetical)|named]]. == See also == * {{mpl|2010 AL|30}} * [[367943 Duende]] == References == {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |type = 2010-04-09 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: (2010 GA6) |url = https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=3514890;cad=1 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 15 February 2018}} {{cite web |title = 2010 GA6 |work = Minor Planet Center |url = https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=2010+GA6 |accessdate = 15 February 2018}} {{Cite web |title=MPEC 2010-G23 : 2010 GA6 |publisher=[[IAU Minor Planet Center]] |date=2010-04-05 |url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K10/K10G23.html |accessdate=2013-02-08}} (K10G06A) {{cite web |date=2010-04-07 |title=Observations of small Solar-System bodies |publisher=hohmanntransfer |url=http://www.hohmanntransfer.com/mn/10/10097_0407.htm#2010GA6 |accessdate=2013-02-08}} ([http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/cgi-bin/ip?1.6e-07 1.6e-07] = 1 in 6,250,000 chance) {{cite web |title = Asteroid to Fly by Within Moon's Orbit Thursday |date = 6 April 2010 |publisher = NASA/JPL |url = https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?release=2010-115 |accessdate = 15 February 2018}} {{cite web |title = Asteroid Size Estimator |publisher = CNEOS NASA/JPL |url = https://cneos.jpl.nasa.gov/tools/ast_size_est.html |accessdate = 15 February 2018}} {{cite web |title=Date/Time Removed |publisher=NASA/JPL Near-Earth Object Program Office |url=http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/risk/removed.html |accessdate=2012-03-19}} {{cite web |date=2010 |title=Earth Impact Effects Program |publisher=Imperial College London / Purdue University |author=Robert Marcus |author2=H. Jay Melosh |author3=Gareth Collins |last-author-amp=yes |url=http://impact.ese.ic.ac.uk/ImpactEffects/ |accessdate=2013-02-04}} (solution using 22 meters, 2600kg/m^3, 17km/s, 45 degrees) {{cite web |date=January 22, 2013 |title=Asteroid Hunter Gives an Update on the Threat of Near-Earth Objects |publisher=[[Scientific American]] |author=Will Ferguson |url=http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/2013/01/22/asteroid-hunter-gives-an-update-on-the-threat-of-near-earth-objects/ |accessdate=2013-01-23}} }} == External links == * [http://www.minorplanetcenter.org/mpec/K10/K10G23.html MPEG], ''[[Minor Planet Electronic Circular]]'', 5 April 2010 * [http://www.foxnews.com/scitech/2010/04/07/newfound-asteroid-buzz-moon-thursday/?test=latestnews Newfound Asteroid to Buzz Earth Thursday], Foxnews * [http://www.universetoday.com/2010/04/06/newly-discovered-asteroid-will-pass-by-earth-april-8/ Newly Discovered Asteroid Will Pass by Earth April 8], UniverseToday.com * {{NeoDys|2010GA6}} * {{JPL small body}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Planetary defense}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2010 GA6}} [[Category:Apollo asteroids|#]] [[Category:Unnumbered minor planets]] [[Category:Discoveries by CSS]] [[Category:Asteroids removed from the Sentry Risk Table]] [[Category:Near-Earth objects in 2010]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 2010|20100405]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|2015 BP|513}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | name = {{mp|2015 BP|513}} | background = #FFC2E0 | image = | caption = | discovery_ref =   | discovered = 27 January 2015 | discoverer = [[Pan-STARRS]] 1
{{small|(first observered)}} | discovery_site = [[Haleakala Observatory|Haleakala Obs.]] | mpc_name = {{mp|2015 BP|513}} | alt_names = | pronounced = | named_after = | mp_category = [[List of Apollo asteroids|Apollo]]{{·}}[[Near-Earth object|NEO]]  | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 16 February 2017 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2457800.5) | uncertainty = 7 | observation_arc = {{nowrap| yr (10 days)}} | aphelion = 2.5160 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 0.9450 AU | semimajor = 1.7305 AU | eccentricity = 0.4539 | period = 2.28 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (831 days) | mean_anomaly = 338.74[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.4330|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 0.4894° | asc_node = 115.43° | arg_peri = 333.76° | moid = 0.0004 AU | dimensions = 12–27 meters | rotation = | albedo = | spectral_type = | abs_magnitude = 26.7 }} '''{{mp|2015 BP|513}}''' (also written [[Astronomical naming conventions#Minor planets|2015 BP513]]) is an [[List of Apollo asteroids|Apollo]] [[near-Earth asteroid]] roughly 12–27 meters in diameter that passed less than 1 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distance]] from Earth on 18 January 2015. ==2015 flyby== Until 18 January 2015 18:00 [[Universal Time|UT]] the small dim asteroid either had an [[Elongation (astronomy)|elongation]] less than 45 degrees from the Sun or was significantly fainter than [[apparent magnitude]] 23. On 18 January 2015 13:36 UT the asteroid passed {{convert|0.00082|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} from the Moon and at 17:09 UT passed {{convert|0.0016|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} from Earth. The asteroid was not discovered until 9 days later on 27 January 2015 by [[Pan-STARRS]] at an apparent magnitude of 21 using a {{convert|1.8|m|in|adj=on|sp=us}} [[Ritchey–Chrétien telescope]]. Two [[precovery]] images from 19 January 2015 when the asteroid was apparent magnitude 16 were then located. == References == {{reflist | refs = {{cite web |type = 2015-01-29 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: (2015 BP513) |url = http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=3709285 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 26 April 2017}} {{cite web |title = 2015 BP513 |work = Minor Planet Center |url = http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=2015+BP513 |accessdate = 26 April 2017}} {{cite web |title=MPEC 2015-B169: 2015 BP513 |publisher=[[IAU Minor Planet Center]] |date=2015-01-30 |url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K15/K15BG9.html |accessdate=2015-02-04}} (K15Bp3P) {{cite web |type=last observation: 2015-01-29; [[Observation arc|arc]]: 10 days |title=JPL Close-Approach Data: (2015 BP513) |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2015BP513;cad=1#cad |accessdate=2015-02-04}} {{cite web |title=Absolute Magnitude (H) |publisher=NASA/JPL |url=http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/glossary/h.html |accessdate=2015-02-04}} {{cite web |title=2015BP513 Ephemerides for 15 January 2015 through 1 February 2015 |publisher=[[NEODyS]] (Near Earth Objects – Dynamic Site) |url=http://newton.dm.unipi.it/neodys/index.php?pc=1.1.3.1&n=2015BP513&oc=500&y0=2015&m0=1&d0=15&h0=0&mi0=0&y1=2015&m1=2&d1=1&h1=0&mi1=0&ti=3&tiu=hours |accessdate=2015-02-04}} }} == External links == * {{JPL small body|id=3709285}} {{use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{2015 in space}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2015 BP513}} [[Category:Apollo asteroids|#]] [[Category:Unnumbered minor planets]] [[Category:Near-Earth objects in 2015|20150118]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 2015|20150127]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/171.76.168.199|171.76.168.199]] identified as test/vandalism using [[WP:STiki|STiki]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=July 2018}} '''Akshayavat''' or '''Akshay Vat''' ("the indestructible banyan tree") is a [[sacred fig]] tree mentioned in the [[Hindu mythology]].
According to a legend, once the sage [[Markandeya]] asked Lord [[Narayana]] to show him a specimen of the divine power. Narayana flooded the entire world for a moment, during which only the Akshayavat could be seen above the water level.<ref name="WCrooke_Religion">{{cite book | title = The Popular Religion and Folklore of Northern India | author = W. Crooke | edition = reprint | publisher = Kessinger | year = 2004 | isbn = 978-1-4179-4902-1 | page = 98 }}</ref>
== Prayag ==
A tree in [[Prayag]] (Allahabad) has been described as Akshayavat in the ''Prayag Mahatmya'' of the ''[[Matsya Purana]]''.<ref name="KM_2008">{{cite book |author=Kama Maclean |title=Pilgrimage and Power: The Kumbh Mela in Allahabad, 1765-1954 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MALacgnsroMC&pg=PA5 |date=28 August 2008 |publisher=OUP USA |isbn=978-0-19-533894-2 |pages=70–73 }}</ref>
In ''The Encyclopaedia Asiatica'' (1976), Edward Balfour identifies a banyan tree mentioned in [[Ramayana]] with the tree at Prayag.<ref name="FJSimoons_Life">{{cite book | title = Plants of life, plants of death | author = Frederick J. Simoons | edition = illustrated | publisher = University of Wisconsin Press | year = 1998 | isbn = 978-0-299-15904-7 | pages = 80–81 }}</ref> [[Rama]], [[Lakshmana]] and [[Sita]] are said to have rested beneath this tree.<ref name="WCrooke_Religion"/> The Chinese Buddhist pilgrim [[Xuanzang]] mentions a tree (a stump with few branches<ref name="FJSimoons_Life"/>) which was said to be the home of a man-eating demon. As part of a custom, some pilgrims would offer themselves at the nearby temple. Xuanzang mentions that the tree was surrounded with the human bones. [[Alexander Cunningham]] identified this tree with the Akshayavat at Prayag.<ref name="WCrooke_Religion"/> [[Rishabha (Jain tirthankar)]] is also said to have practised [[tapasya]] beneath the historical Akshayavat at Prayag.
Currently, a sacred fig tree located within the Patalpuri Temple at the [[Allahabad Fort]] is worshipped as the Akshayavat described in ancient texts. {{As of|2011}}, a permission from the Commandant of Allahabad Fort's Ordnance Depot is needed to visit this tree. On one day during the [[Allahabad Kumbh Mela|Kumbh Mela]], the site is open to all the pilgrims. However, a popular opinion is that the Patalpuri Temple tree is not the authentic Akshayavat: the real Akshayavat is in another underground temple inside the Fort. When the British gained control of the Allahabad Fort after the [[Treaty of Allahabad]] in 1765, they did not want general public to access the sensitive parts of the fort. So, the shrine was moved to fringes of the fort compound, that is, the present-day Patalpuri Temple.<ref name="KM_2008"/> According to the Welsh travel writer [[Fanny Parkes]], who visited both the tree sites in 1831, when the original Akshayavat chamber was closed, the local Brahmins set up the stump of a [[Ziziphus mauritiana|ber tree]] in Patalpuri. They claimed that it was a branch of the original Akshayavat that had penetrated through the walls, and made a lot of money from pilgrims visiting it during the [[Allahabad Kumbh Mela|fair]]. Parkes states that the local Hindus of Prayag knew about this "trick", and did not worship the false Akshayavat.<ref>{{cite book |author=Fanny Parks Parlby |title=Wanderings of a Pilgrim in Search of the Picturesque: During Four-and-twenty Years in the East |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fFwLAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA215 |year=1850 |publisher=Pelham Richardson |pages=215–216 }}</ref> An 18th century map of the Fort from the [[British Library]] confirms this: the location of the original temple is shown in the center of the fort; while the present-day Patalpuri Temple is on the outskirts of the Fort. In the 1950s, [[Shiva Nath Katju]] also claimed that the "tree" placed in the Patalpuri Temple was only a log that was replaced by the priests every 4–5 years. The commander of the fort acknowledged his claim as true.<ref name="KM_2008"/>
== Other places == [[File:Akshay Vat, The Banyan Tree Witness to The Gita, Kurukshetra, India.jpg|thumb|300px|A tree at [[Kurukshetra]], claimed to be the Akshay Vat]] A tree at [[Gaya, Bihar]]<ref name="FJSimoons_Life"/><ref>''The Sacred Complex in Hindu Gaya'', Concept. Page 9.</ref> and another tree at [[Varanasi]] are also worshipped as the Akshayavat. The [[Bodhi tree]] is said to be a manifestation of the Akashayavat at Prayag.<ref name="himalayan_kumbha">{{cite web | url = http://www.kumbhamelatimes.org/pointsarchive.asp?dt=1/12/2001 | title = Akshaya Vata: The Eternal Banyan Tree | publisher = The Himalayan Institute | date = 2001-12-01 | accessdate = 2011-03-15 }}</ref>
According to Tibetan Buddhist tradition, [[Buddha]] is said to have planted a seed of the Prayag's Akshayavat next to [[Mount Kailash]] on a mountain known as the Palace of the Medicine Buddha.<ref name="himalayan_kumbha"/>
== See also == * [[Kalpavriksha]], a mythological, wish-fulfilling divine tree
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Worship in Hinduism}}

revision.comment: Spelling of deciduous corrected; Italian takes capital 'I'.
revision.text:
[[File:MonteCimone1.jpg|thumb|250px|Mixed forest (Abies alba and Fagus sylvatica) in Cimone Mountain, northern Apennine]] The '''Apennine deciduous montane forests''', a [[temperate broadleaf and mixed forests]] [[biome]], are an [[ecoregion]] in the mountain ranges of Italian peninsula including the [[Apennine Mountains]]. The development of these forests is ensured by the high rainfall Apennines (from 1000 mm in southern Apennine to 2500 mm in northern Apennine), combined with a temperate-cool climate. Because of climate change, the presence of Silver Fir ([[Abies alba]]), although still widespread, is dramatically reduced in favour of the beech. ==Description== ===Vegetation zones=== The ecoregion has two major vegetation zones:
1. Extensive forests *''[[Fagus sylvatica]]'' *Silver Fir ''[[Abies alba]]'' (mixed with beech) *some relict ''[[Pinus nigra]]'' var. ''italica'' stands. *some relict ''[[Picea abies]]'' and ''[[Pinus sylvestris]]'' (only in Northern Apennine). With presence of deciduous [[Quercus]] ssp. and sporadic [[Fraxinus]] ssp., [[Acer (plant)|Acer]] ssp., [[Tilia]] ssp., [[Populus]] ssp., [[Castanea sativa]], [[Carpinus]] ssp., [[Ostrya]] ssp., [[Ulmus]] ssp., [[Betula]] ssp., [[Sorbus]] ssp., [[Salix]] ssp., [[Prunus]] ssp., [[Taxus baccata]], [[Malus sylvestris]], [[Pyrus]] and other Central-European broadleaved and coniferous species. 2. Mountain summit meadows and cushion scrubs, with the predominant species: *''[[Juniperus nana]]'', *''[[Sorbus chamaemespilus]]'', *''[[Arctostaphylos uva-ursi]]'', *''[[Vaccinium vitis-idaea]]'' *relict ''[[Pinus mugo]]'' (Majella Mountain). ===Endemic species=== There are a high number of [[endemic species]] increasing at higher elevations and representing between 10 and 20% of the total flora. *[[Abruzzi|Abruzzo Mountains]] has 1,200 endemic species; *[[Gran Sasso]] and [[Monti della Laga]] has 1,500 endemic species; *[[Majella|Maiella mountains]] has 1,800 endemic species. Alpine species include *''[[Gentiana dinarica]]'', *''[[Gentiana nivalis]]'', *''[[Androsace alpina]]'', *''[[Polygala chamaebuxus]]'', *''[[Saxifraga oppositifolia]]'', *''[[Ranunculus seguieri]]'' *''[[Carlina acaulis]]''. ==External links== *{{WWF ecoregion|id=pa0401|name=Appenine''[sic]'' Deciduous Montane Forests}} {{-}} {{Paleartic temperate broadleaf and mixed forests}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Apennine deciduous montane forest}} [[Category:Temperate broadleaf and mixed forests]] [[Category:Ecoregions of Italy]] [[Category:Apennine Mountains]] [[Category:Flora of Italy|*]] [[Category:Montane forests]] [[Category:Ecoregions of Europe]] [[Category:Palearctic ecoregions]]

revision.text:
The '''Askaryan radiation'''<ref>{{Cite journal |arxiv = 1605.04975|last1 = Hanson|first1 = Jordan C|title = Complex Analysis of Askaryan Radiation: A Fully Analytic Treatment including the LPM effect and Cascade Form Factor|journal = Astroparticle Physics|volume = 91|pages = 75–89|last2 = Connolly|first2 = Amy L|year = 2016|doi = 10.1016/j.astropartphys.2017.03.008|bibcode = 2017APh....91...75H}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |arxiv = 1106.6283|last1 = Hanson|first1 = Jordan C|title = Practical and accurate calculations of Askaryan radiation |journal = Physical Review D|volume = 84|issue = 10|last2 = Connolly|first2 = Amy L|last3 = Zas|first3 = Enrique|year = 2011|doi = 10.1103/PhysRevD.84.103003|bibcode = 2011PhRvD..84j3003A}}</ref> also known as '''Askaryan effect''' is the phenomenon whereby a particle traveling faster than the phase [[velocity]] of [[light]] in a dense [[dielectric]] (such as salt, ice or the [[Moon|lunar]] [[regolith]]) produces a shower of secondary charged particles which contain a charge [[anisotropy]] and thus emits a cone of [[Coherence (physics)|coherent]] radiation in the [[radio frequency|radio]] or [[microwave]] part of the [[electromagnetic spectrum]]. It is similar to the [[Cherenkov radiation]]. It is named after [[Gurgen Askaryan]], a Soviet-Armenian physicist who postulated it in 1962.
The radiation was first observed experimentally in 2000, 38 years after its theoretical prediction. So far the effect has been observed in [[silicon dioxide|silica]] [[sand]],<ref>{{Cite journal |arxiv = hep-ex/0011001|last1 = Hanson|first1 = Jordan C|title = Observation of the Askaryan Effect: Coherent Microwave Cherenkov Emission from Charge Asymmetry in High Energy Particle Cascades |journal = Physical Review Letters|volume = 86|issue = 13|pages = 2802–5|last2 = Connolly|first2 = Amy L|last3 = Walz|first3 = D|last4 = Field|first4 = C|last5 = Iverson|first5 = R|last6 = Odian|first6 = A|last7 = Resch|first7 = G|last8 = Schoessow|first8 = P|last9 = Williams|first9 = D|year = 2000|doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.86.2802|pmid = 11290043|bibcode = 2001PhRvL..86.2802S}}</ref> rock salt,<ref>{{Cite journal |arxiv = astro-ph/0412128|last1 = Hanson|first1 = Jordan C|title = Accelerator Measurements of the Askaryan effect in Rock Salt: A Roadmap Toward Teraton Underground Neutrino Detectors |journal = Physical Review D|volume = 72|issue = 2|last2 = Connolly|first2 = Amy L|last3 = Field|first3 = R. C|last4 = Guillian|first4 = E|last5 = Milinčić|first5 = R|last6 = Miočinović|first6 = P|last7 = Walz|first7 = D|last8 = Williams|first8 = D|year = 2004|doi = 10.1103/PhysRevD.72.023002|url = http://cds.cern.ch/record/809174|format = Submitted manuscript|bibcode = 2005PhRvD..72b3002G}}</ref> ice,<ref>{{Cite journal |arxiv = hep-ex/0611008|last1 = Hanson|first1 = Jordan C|title = Observations of the Askaryan Effect in Ice |journal = Physical Review Letters|volume = 99|issue = 17|pages = 171101|last2 = Connolly|first2 = Amy L|last3 = Beatty|first3 = J. J|last4 = Besson|first4 = D. Z|last5 = Binns|first5 = W. R|last6 = Chen|first6 = C|last7 = Chen|first7 = P|last8 = Clem|first8 = J. M|last9 = Connolly|first9 = A|last10 = Dowkontt|first10 = P. F|last11 = Duvernois|first11 = M. A|last12 = Field|first12 = R. C|last13 = Goldstein|first13 = D|last14 = Goodhue|first14 = A|last15 = Hast|first15 = C|last16 = Hebert|first16 = C. L|last17 = Hoover|first17 = S|last18 = Israel|first18 = M. H|last19 = Kowalski|first19 = J|last20 = Learned|first20 = J. G|last21 = Liewer|first21 = K. M|last22 = Link|first22 = J. T|last23 = Lusczek|first23 = E|last24 = Matsuno|first24 = S|last25 = Mercurio|first25 = B|last26 = Miki|first26 = C|last27 = Miočinović|first27 = P|last28 = Nam|first28 = J|last29 = Naudet|first29 = C. J|last30 = Ng|first30 = J|year = 2007|doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.99.171101|pmid = 17995315|displayauthors = 29|bibcode = 2007PhRvL..99q1101G}}</ref> and Earth's atmosphere.<ref>{{Cite journal |arxiv = 1603.01594|last1 = Hanson|first1 = Jordan C |title = A large light-mass component of cosmic rays at 10<sup>17</sup>–10<sup>17.5</sup> electronvolts from radio observations|journal = Nature|volume = 531|issue = 7592|pages = 70–3|last2 = Connolly|first2 = Amy L|last3 = Falcke|first3 = H|last4 = Hörandel|first4 = J. R|last5 = Huege|first5 = T|last6 = Nelles|first6 = A|last7 = Rachen|first7 = J. P|last8 = Rossetto|first8 = L|last9 = Schellart|first9 = P|last10 = Scholten|first10 = O|last11 = Ter Veen|first11 = S|last12 = Thoudam|first12 = S|last13 = Trinh|first13 = T. N. G|last14 = Anderson|first14 = J|last15 = Asgekar|first15 = A|last16 = Avruch|first16 = I. M|last17 = Bell|first17 = M. E|last18 = Bentum|first18 = M. J|last19 = Bernardi|first19 = G|last20 = Best|first20 = P|last21 = Bonafede|first21 = A|last22 = Breitling|first22 = F|last23 = Broderick|first23 = J. W|last24 = Brouw|first24 = W. N|last25 = Brüggen|first25 = M|last26 = Butcher|first26 = H. R|last27 = Carbone|first27 = D|last28 = Ciardi|first28 = B|last29 = Conway|first29 = J. E|last30 = De Gasperin|first30 = F|year = 2016|doi = 10.1038/nature16976|pmid = 26935696|displayauthors = 29|bibcode = 2016Natur.531...70B}}</ref>
The effect is of primary interest in using bulk matter to detect ultra-high energy [[neutrino]]s. The [[Antarctic Impulse Transient Antenna]] (ANITA) experiment uses antennas attached to a balloon flying over [[Antarctica]] to detect the Askaryan radiation produced as cosmic neutrinos travel through the ice.<ref>[http://www.ps.uci.edu/~anita/ ANITA Project Overview]</ref><ref>[http://arianna.ps.uci.edu/ ARIANNA collaboration]</ref> Several experiments have also used the [[Moon]] as a [[neutrino detector]] based on detection of the Askaryan radiation.<ref>[http://www.physics.ucla.edu/~moonemp/public/ GLUE project]</ref><ref>[http://www.kvi.nl/~scholten/numoon/numoon.html NuMoon project]</ref><ref>[http://www.physics.adelaide.edu.au/astrophysics/lunaska/index.html LUNASKA project]</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100708190312/http://resun.physics.uiowa.edu/ RESUN project]</ref>

[[Category:Particle physics]] [[Category:Physical phenomena]]

{{Unreferenced|date=June 2017}} '''Cap carbonates''' are layers of distinctively textured [[carbonate rock]]s which typically form the uppermost layer of [[sedimentary]] sequences reflecting major glaciations in the geological record.
The rising temperatures, and increased oceanic surface area - due to reduced ice cover and rising sea levels - at the end of a glaciation increase the rate of [[precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]].
High concentrations of [[greenhouse gas]]es such as [[carbon dioxide]] (CO<sub>2</sub>) must build up in the atmosphere to overcome the effect of the high reflectivity ([[albedo]]) of ice and allow temperatures to rise sufficiently to begin melting.
Increased precipitation dissolves carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, falling as a weak [[carbonic acid]] - [[acid rain]].
This would weather exposed [[silicate]] and carbonate rock, including readily-attacked glacial debris, which would release large amounts of calcium. When washed into the ocean, these [[precipitation (chemistry)|precipitate]] to form distinctively textured layers of carbonate [[sedimentary rock]].
A heavily debated cap carbonate appears at the top of the [[Gaskiers glaciation (geology)|Gaskiers glaciation]], believed by many to be [[Snowball Earth|global in extent]].
== See also == * [[Marinoan glaciation]] * [[Sturtian glaciation]] * [[Ediacaran#Boundaries_of_the_Ediacaran|Boundaries of the Ediacaran Period]]
==References== {{reflist}} * [http://www.snowballearth.org/capcarbs.html What are Cap Carbonates?] at www.snowballearth.org

{{Infobox rockunit | name = Cañadón Asfalto Formation | image = Cañadón Asfalto formation.png | caption = Formation map and location | type = [[Geological formation]] | period = Toarcian | age = [[Toarcian|Mid Toarcian]]-[[Bajocian]]
~{{fossilrange|178|168}} | prilithology = [[Sandstone]] | otherlithology = [[Limestone]], [[shale]], [[conglomerate (geology)|conglomerate]], [[tuffite]] | namedfor = | namedby = | region = [[Chubut Province]],
[[Patagonia]] | country = {{ARG}} | coordinates = {{coord|43.4|S|69.2|W|display=inline,title}} | paleocoordinates = {{coord|40.5|S|29.3|W|display=inline}} | unitof = [[Sierra de Olte Group]] | subunits = Las Chacritas Member, ? Puesto Almada Member | underlies = [[Cañadón Calcáreo Formation]] | overlies = [[Lonco Trapial Formation]] | thickness = {{convert|600|m|ft|abbr=on}} | extent = [[Cañadón Asfalto Basin]] | area = | map = | map_caption = }} The '''Cañadón Asfalto Formation''' is a [[Early Jurassic]] to [[Middle Jurassic]] [[geologic formation]], from the [[Jurassic]] period of the [[Mesozoic]] Era. It was formerly thought to be Mid to Late Jurassic in age, but [[Uranium–lead dating|Uranium-Lead dating]] of the volcanic tuff beds have revised the age to the mid [[Toarcian]] to sometime in the Mid Jurassic, probably the [[Bajocian]].{{Cite journal|last=Cúneo|first=Rubén|last2=Ramezani|first2=Jahandar|last3=Scasso|first3=Roberto|last4=Pol|first4=Diego|last5=Escapa|first5=Ignacio|last6=Zavattieri|first6=Ana M.|last7=Bowring|first7=Samuel A.|date=2013-11|title=High-precision U–Pb geochronology and a new chronostratigraphy for the Cañadón Asfalto Basin, Chubut, central Patagonia: Implications for terrestrial faunal and floral evolution in Jurassic|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1342937X13000609|journal=Gondwana Research|volume=24|issue=3-4|pages=1267–1275|doi=10.1016/j.gr.2013.01.010|issn=1342-937X}} It is located in the [[Cañadón Asfalto Basin]], a [[rift basin]] in [[Chubut Province]] of northwestern [[Patagonia]], in southern [[Argentina]].{{cite journal|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0037073812003247 | doi=10.1016/j.sedgeo.2012.11.008 | volume=284-285 | title=Sedimentology and paleoenvironments of the Las Chacritas carbonate paleolake, Cañadón Asfalto Formation (Jurassic), Patagonia, Argentina | year=2013 | journal=Sedimentary Geology | pages=91–105 | last1 = Cabaleri | first1 = Nora G. | last2 = Benavente | first2 = Cecilia A.}} The basin started forming in the earliest Jurassic.Figari et al., 2015, p.142 It is composed of fluvial-[[lacustrine deposits]], typically sandstones and shales with a saline paleolake carbonate evaporitic sequence of [[limestone]] in its lowest Las Chacritas Member.[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/273910660_The_palynology_of_the_Canadon_Asfalto_Formation_Jurassic_Cerro_Condor_depocentre_Canadon_Asfalto_Basin_Patagonia_Argentina_Palaeoecology_and_palaeoclimate_based_on_ecogroup_analysis Researchgate.net: "The palynology of the Cañadón Asfalto Formation (Jurassic), Cerro Cóndor depocentre, Cañadón Asfalto Basin, Patagonia, Argentina: Palaeoecology and palaeoclimate based on ecogroup analysis"] Interbedded with these are volcanic tuffites. It is divided into two members, the Las Chacritas Member, and the overlying Puesto Almada member, but the latter has also been assigned to the overlying [[Cañadón Calcáreo Formation]] by other authors.{{Cite journal|last=Rauhut|first=Oliver W. M.|last2=Pol|first2=Diego|date=2017-11|title=A Theropod Dinosaur from the Late Jurassic Cañadón Calcáreo Formation of Central Patagonia, and the Evolution of the Theropod Tarsus|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/10.5710/AMGH.12.10.2017.3105|journal=Ameghiniana|language=en-US|volume=54|issue=5|pages=539–566|doi=10.5710/amgh.12.10.2017.3105|issn=0002-7014}} According to a palynological study the dominant pollen was produced by the conifer families Cheirolepidiaceae (''Classopollis'') and Araucariaceae (mainly ''Araucariacites'' and ''Callialasporites''), suggesting that warm-temperate and relatively humid conditions under highly seasonal climate prevailed during the depositional times of the unit. The abundance of ''Botryococcus'' supports the presence of a shallow lake with probably saline conditions.{{Cite book|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/273910660_The_palynology_of_the_Canadon_Asfalto_Formation_Jurassic_Cerro_Condor_depocentre_Canadon_Asfalto_Basin_Patagonia_Argentina_Palaeoecology_and_palaeoclimate_based_on_ecogroup_analysis|title=The palynology of the Cañadón Asfalto Formation (Jurassic), Cerro Cóndor depocentre, Cañadón Asfalto Basin, Patagonia, Argentina: Palaeoecology and palaeoclimate based on ecogroup analysis|last=Olivera|first=Daniela|last2=Zavattieri|first2=Ana|last3=Quattrocchio|first3=Mirta|date=2015-03-11|volume=39}} ==Vertebrate fauna== ===Amphibians=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! colspan="7" align="center" |'''[[Amphibian]]s reported from the Cañadon Asfalto Formation''' |- ! Genus ! Species ! Location ! Stratigraphic position ! Material ! Notes ! revision.text:
{{Infobox protected area | name = Coronado National Memorial | iucn_category = III | map = USA#Arizona | relief = 1 | map_caption = | location = [[Cochise County, Arizona]], [[United States|USA]] | nearest_city = [[Sierra Vista, Arizona]] | coordinates = {{coords|31|20|54|N|110|16|18|W|region:US|display=inline, title}} | area_acre = 4,750.22 | established = November 5, 1952 | visitation_num = 136,075 | visitation_year = 2016 | visitation_ref = <ref>{{NPS visitation|accessdate=2017-05-15}}</ref> | governing_body = [[National Park Service]] | website = [https://www.nps.gov/coro/ Coronado National Memorial] }} The '''Coronado National Memorial''' commemorates the first organized expedition into the Southwest by [[conquistador]] [[Francisco Vásquez de Coronado]]. The memorial is located in a natural setting on the international border on the southeast flank of the [[Huachuca Mountains]] south of [[Sierra Vista, Arizona]]. The memorial confirms the ties that bind the [[United States]] and [[Mexico]].
==Memorial development== Official statements indicate that it was initially designed as a gesture of goodwill and cooperation between the United States and Mexico, through the recognition of Coronado's 1540 expedition to the area. For example, in 1939 the [[United States House Committee on International Relations|House Committee on Foreign Affairs]] noted:
:As a result of this expedition, what has been truly characterized by historians as one of the greatest land expeditions the world has known, a new civilization was established in the great American Southwest.
And [[E. K. Burlew]], Acting [[United States Secretary of the Interior|Secretary of the Interior]] added in 1940:
:To commemorate permanently the explorations of Francisco Vásquez de Coronado. . .would be of great value in advancing the relationship of the United States and Mexico upon a friendly basis of cultural understanding. . . [It would] stress the history and problems of the two countries and would encourage cooperation for the advancement of their common interests.
Thus the site was first designated '''Coronado International Memorial''' on August 18, 1941, with the hope that a comparable adjoining area would be established in Mexico. The arrangement might have been similar to the [[Waterton-Glacier International Peace Park]] between the United States and [[Canada]]. However, despite interest by the government of Mexico, the Mexican memorial was never created, therefore Congress changed the authorized designation to a [[national memorial]] on July 9, 1952. The memorial was established by Harry S. Truman on November 5 of that year. As with all historic areas administered by the [[National Park Service]], the national memorial was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] on October 15, 1966.
==Gallery== <gallery class="center" mode=packed> File:Coronado park97.jpg|NPS Park map File:Entrada Reenactment.jpeg|Reenactment of [[Francisco Vásquez de Coronado|Coronado]]'s entrada, 1540 File:Coronado-natl-memorial.jpg|Visitors at Coronado National Memorial </gallery>
==References== {{Reflist}} * ''The National Parks: Index 2001–2003''. Washington: [[United States Department of the Interior|U.S. Department of the Interior]].
==External links== * Official NPS website: [http://www.nps.gov/coro/ Coronado National Memorial] * [http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/travel/amsw/ American Southwest, a National Park Service ''Discover Our Shared Heritage'' Travel Itinerary]
